data.text: Why Use a Touring Bike instead of a Bikepacking Gravel Bike?

I‘m following the group silently for a while. Is there any reason why apparently most of the „bicycle travellers“ in this group are using touring bikes instead of bikepacking gravel bikes for example?
If you’re going on a long tour, wouldn’t a touring setup allow for more cargo capacity?

data.text: touring bikes also have longer chainstays to avoid scraping your shoes on an expected large Pannier in back. They are specifically designed for large loading and long trips. data.text: If you mostly stay on public roads touring bike is a better setup as it allows you to cover longer distances with fewer headaches. Suppose you go off the paved roads a lot (singletrack trail where trees, rocks, and roots are a factor) bikepacking setup with softer frame attachments and a slimmer profile gravel bike with thicker tires may be a better choice. It will be slower on roads, though.

data.text: I think a bikepacking set up is really useful where a) you’re travelling light and b) the trail might get pretty rough. Heavy luggage and bumpy roads will take a toll on a pannier rack, causing metal fatigue and eventual breakage. Where nylon bags are simply strapped to the bike frame, you don’t get any stress points, so it should endure an off-road route quite well, and you can easily carry spare straps. Partly it’s just fashion but hey, why not? All bikes are brilliant in my opinion.

data.text: I ride a touring bike but, its equally good on gravel. Sometimes, i bikepack with panniers and sometimes with front, mid and backloader bags. It depends on where im going, how, far, how long, if im camping or hostelling and weather. 1550 miles into a 2000 trip but, having a family break before the final 350 mile journey home. Used front and rear panniers for this trip and, rode some very rough tracks from time to time. Repacked for the final leg and, as i wont need so much kit, will use smaller rear panniers and have ditched the front bags.

That said, I've still rode some gnarly sections, the most 'memorable' being trails through the Congo & D.R. Congo enroute to Cape Town.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: I bought my new steel frame gravel bike with the intention that I could tour with it, however, to accommodate the possibility of touring with others who had touring bikes I made sure to buy a gravel bike with two front chain rings to add the possibility of greater speed and also decent climbing gears. Many new gravel bikes have all the necessary braze-ons to add the necessary racks etc. for touring. Any touring bike with wheels and tires from 700 x32 or larger are good in gravel. For that matter any old mountain bike with two or three front rings can be used as a gravel bike or to tour as well if set up with dual purpose tires rather than just knobby tires. I was in a bike accident where I had a shoulder injury. For a while, during recovery, I made my old 1999 Rocky Mountain Hammer Race into a hybrid by raising the handle bars and adding Michelin Protek Urban tires 26 x 1.85. The front suspension and wider tires helped for comfort with my injured shoulder and I was able to ride 60 to 85km rides during recovery. Now that I have the gravel bike the Rocky Mountain is returned to a vintage mountain bike.

data.text: It’s been said before…”Its not about the bike” Form will follow function. I see the different bike styles as means to an end. The variables of speed, environment, reliability, time, remoteness, comfort required and mental purpose will determine what your bike needs evolve into. This FB page title says it al….’Bike Travellers’. Whether it be road, gravel or ice. Get on whatever bike you have, wherever you are and let the journey begin. This is a great page for advice, but only if we leave ego and judgment out of it. I learned my best lessons from my mistakes. Just my 2cents worth.
data.author: Manna Gumball

data.text: Whatever the bike we use, we are traveler, more touring setup around the world even if bike-packing is growing well. For my part, I ride my Surly LHT since years, every where and I consider bike touring a slow way of traveling, so, I can carry food for days and not spend any money in hostel or restaurant if I want to
data.author: Adrien Gss

data.text: Panniers are better for carrying stuff - more of it, easier to pack and organise. I have been touring for years on a classic touring bike, but have recently got a bike that can take wider tyres and with better geometry to handle gravel roads and trails. But I will still be using rear panniers, although adding bikepacking gear (frame bag, cargo cages on the fork) if I need more capacity.
data.author: David Backhouse

data.text: well. many "trails" in the mountains don't allow bicycles (Banff and Jasper, and other national parks) with one exception the Great Divide Mountain Bike route that starts in Banff and ends in New Mexico, USA. that allows bicycles, and they highly recommend a mountain bike set up, so a bikepacking type using mountain bikes. but many people would choose a touring bike set up because its easier to just go on a road and just cycle. I personally have a gravel type touring bike, but I swapped out the tires as the original tires weren't strong enough as I went on a 1300 mile, (2000 km) trip and ended up getting flats 5 times over that trip. and I was disappointed. so I switched to a more robust and stronger tire that has better protection.

data.text: For me personaly, a handful of reasons. - Price. When I started out, the touring bikes were more affordable. - Granny gears. - I want the option of fully loaded touring (four panneirs), and not just UL bike packing. That does not mean that I have not looked at gravel bikes. The 1x drivetrains are of little use to me, but the 2x would be more interesting.
